data.title: Raising a family in the 'last frontier', Billings Olympic archer Brady Ellison has no plans to slow down
data.meta_description: Brady Ellison and his family have found the perfect fit in Montana.
data.text:
BILLINGS — Talk about being prepared.

When Olympic archery five-time medal winner Brady Ellison walks out of the garage door at his residence near the Briarwood Golf Club south of Billings, there is a target 77 yards away.

The 77-yard measurement is the Olympic shooting distance, Ellison noted. On his 32-acre spread — “we got super lucky with this place” — Ellison has other targets, including one of a deer the avid hunter can shoot at.

On Wednesday afternoon, just under two days from arriving back in the Magic City from the Paris Olympics with a silver and bronze medal in tow, Ellison, 35, was answering questions and posing for pictures with The Billings Gazette and 406 MT Sports at his Billings home.

It's a perfect place for the Ellison family as Brady’s wife of eight years is Toja Ellison, a native of Slovenia who still shoots for her country’s national team.

In the basement is a 20-yard archery range, although the distance can be stretched to 40 yards. There is also a weight room. The indoor range can double as a play area for the couple’s two children, nearly 4-year-old son Ty and 6-month-old son Bo.

“We built an archery range and then put a house on top of it to live in,” said Ellison, a professional archer who spends approximately 35 to 40 hours a week practicing his sport.

The family has lived in Billings approximately three years after moving from Globe, Arizona.

“I love it up here. I mean it’s why we moved up here,” said Ellison, a Globe native. “I fell in love with Montana a long time ago coming up here hunting and just fell in love with the area and fell in love with everything up here. And, then when we decided to move up here, like finding a place that we liked and the wife wanted somewhere that we had neighbors and stuff, but I wanted somewhere that we had a little bit of land and could see animals all the time and stuff. ... It's a good mix for us.”

As a person who loves to hunt for deer, elk and pronghorn, along with occasional bird hunting — “I hunt everything” — Ellison has netted five or six elk, including two in Montana. He has antlers from his successful hunts that some would dream of. And while Ellison is a world-class competitive archer, he does occasionally hunt with a rifle.

“Mostly archery. I love hunting with a bow, but I am an equal opportunist and I love hunting with a rifle, too,” he said. “I like all hunting, it doesn’t matter to me. But generally, the archery season lines up in my schedule a little better when it’s kind of slower, the off times. And since I shoot a bow every day all day, it’s more fun to go hunt that way for me. But I’m not afraid to pull the trigger on a rifle, either.”

A five-time Olympian — competing in Beijing in 2008, London in 2012, Rio de Janeiro in 2016, Tokyo in 2021 and Paris — Ellison has won three silver medals and two bronze medals in his career.

On Sunday, Ellison achieved a silver medal in the men’s individual archery competition and he teamed with 20-year-old Casey Kaufhold of Lancaster, Pennsylvania, to earn a bronze in the mixed team archery event Friday.

In addition to the two medals in Paris, Ellison won silver and bronze in Rio de Janeiro and silver in London. He is the all-time United States leader in Olympic archery medals. In all of Olympic history, only Koreans have earned more medals than Ellison.

“When we won the bronze, it was kind of a historic thing,” he said. “I didn’t even realize it at the time. That bronze was the first medal in 35 years that a woman has won, since the '88 Games that was the last time a U.S. woman won an Olympic medal. That became my fourth (medal), which made me the medal count winner in the USA. And then the fifth obviously added to that. So now, I guess I’m the most decorated Olympic archer the U.S. has ever had.”

Ellison has accomplished much over his archery career, including winning 18 medals — eight golds, three silvers and seven bronzes — at the World Championships. Ellison credits his love of the outdoors for helping him become the archer he is today.

“I just started hunting when I was a kid with a bow and then it just kind of grew from there,” he explained. “And then I got some lucky breaks, coaches noticing me at the right time. I moved out to California in 2006, when I was still a junior in high school, and it was supposed to be a three-month trial program. And it turns into me living out there for 10 years, working with a national coach and just training full-time out there and then just luck into five medals.”

In the gold medal match in the men’s individual archery event in Paris, Kim Woo-jin of South Korea won in a shootout. In the shootout, both archers scored 10 points on a single arrow, however the Korean’s arrow was closer to the center.

Standing next to one of his outdoor targets, Ellison demonstrated just how close the shootout was by sticking arrows into the target. Ellison was oh-so close to a gold medal.

“Five millimeters, like a 16th of an inch away from winning gold,” he said. “Just barely.”

While Ellison would have loved a gold, he’s content with the results of the match — which he said then was one of the best Olympic finals ever.

“I shot great. I did my game plan. I didn’t really mess anything up,” he said. “And in the end, we had a great match and I just barely got beat. I mean, we’re talking five millimeters ain’t that much.

“I shot a good match and I put on a good show and at the end of the day, I got to shoot in front of that crowd till the very end. So that’s kind of the main goal.”

A strong fanbase helped Ellison. The main cheerleaders were his wife and children, but he said spectators also played a part in his Olympic glory. And although he’s a relative newcomer to the Treasure State, more and more Montanans have begun rooting for him, especially since he was able to recently change his Team USA bio and list his hometown as Billings.

“You can’t do this without fans and without help and without people,” Ellison said. “When I got out there and win a medal, I’m the one winning a medal but there’s a thousand, a hundred thousand, a million people who helped me get here. And the people in Montana have been super awesome to me. Not a lot of people knew that I was from here, or that I was an Olympian, but that’s completely OK. And I didn’t come up here to be like, ‘Hey, look at me.’ I came up here to raise a family in the last frontier.”

A goal of Ellison’s is to continue to stay at a high level and make the Olympic team for 2028 in Los Angeles.

Ellison said he competes in about 20 events a year, about half in foreign countries.

“It’s my job. It’s how I pay my bills. I’m a little young to retire,” he said. “I’m still in the top 10 in the world and should be in the top five in the world now. I’m still the No. 1 guy in the U.S. So, I’ll continue doing this and competing until I’m no longer able to make a team and until enough guys come up and beat me and then I can no longer pay my bills, so I’ll retire and do something else.”

Sponsorships help professional archers with income, but Ellison has to maintain his game to have a good payday.

“Sponsors help out, but a majority of the money I make is from winning tournaments,” he said. “Even from sponsors and stuff, they have a contingency if you place first and second or third it’s a set amount of money. The more I win, the more I make.”

Ellison departed for Paris on July 18. While in France, athletes with Team USA were busy focusing on giving their best efforts. Much of their days before the competition were riding a bus to the practice field, practicing and having lunch, and then riding the bus back to the Olympic village, where they ate and slept.

There wasn’t much time for fun, as the athletes were there for business.

“All of us had been to Paris so many times,” Ellison said. “World Archery has had a World Cup there for four years leading up to the Games, so we’ve been going to Paris since 2021. So, all of us had kind of seen everything and done everything touristy already. So, it was more just focused on that and enjoying the Olympics more than going and seeing the Eiffel Tower and all that stuff. … You’re there to do a job.”

While Ellison was looking forward to spending some time with his family after the hectic time in Paris, he leaves Tuesday for the USA Archery Target Nationals and U.S. Open next week in Lubbock, Texas.

He admitted the travel can be tough, “but you get used to it. I’ve been doing this and traveling like this for almost 18 years. We have stretches where it’s back-to-back-to-back weekends, then a weekend off and then you have three more tournaments. It’s just kind of what it is.”

In Paris, it was enjoyable for Ellison to have Toja, Ty and Bo there.

“It was awesome. I would hear Ty yelling; everyone would be quiet and then he’d yell at me. It was pretty cool,” he said.

Ellison met his wife at a World Cup event in Colombia and the two will be shooting at the World Archery Field Championships Sept. 16-22 in Lac La Biche, Alberta, Canada. Brady will shoot for the United States and Toja for Slovenia.

“It’s awesome and we train together as much as we can,” said Ellison. “It’s hard for us both to shoot. With the kids, generally she’ll shoot and I’ll take care of the kids and vice-versa and we’ll give each other time that way. It’s awesome training and traveling together because the whole entire family goes to all my national events together. We just get an Airbnb and the whole family comes and we hang out. Ty runs around and says ‘Hi’ to all his friends at the archery tournament and we just do it all as a big family.”

While they pursue their goals, the Ellisons said they can’t think of a better place to be than Billings.

“Look at the property. We have so many great sledding hills and I didn’t realize I liked snow so much until moving up here. I had been in the snow when I was younger. Where we lived, we were up in elevation. We were almost a mile high, so we got quite a bit of snow in the winter,” said Ellison. “But I never went sledding or did any of that kind of stuff. And now that we sled and do all that in the yard with the boys all the time and stuff, it is awesome. Like we have one run when we get enough snow that it’s about a 400- to 500-yard sled run. That’s super fun.”

Photos: Billings Olympian Brady Ellison returns home after Paris Games

Briarwood residents cheer as five-time Olympian and Billings resident Brady Ellison makes his way home from the 2024 Olympics in Paris. Ellison won a silver medal in Men's Individual Archery and a bronze medal in Mixed Team Archery at this year's Olympic Games.

Email Gazette Sports Editor John Letasky at john.letasky@406mtsports.com or follow him on X/Twitter at @GazSportsJohnL
